relation: The cameras in the Ixus line-up lack a physical aperture and use an ND filter instead.
See also: Ixus. Look up equivalent model in P-ID (Table)
SX40 HS*, SX50 HS*, SX220 HS*, S230 HS*, SX240 HS, SX260 HS
textBeforeTable: List of cameras with ND filter set_nd_filter() - 0=auto, 1=in, 2=out get_nd_present() - return status indicates whether camera has an ND filter and/or a diaphragm ND Filter Scripting Functions Some higher end cameras have both an ND filter and a real aperture, e.g the cameras of the G series. Not all cameras have an ND filter; all cameras of the Ixus series have a ND Filter instead of a real aperture, also some other ones, e.g. the A450, A460, A530, A550, A560, A1000, TX1. Notes: 'Out' means the ND filter is not in. 'In' means the ND filter is swung in. 'Off' means the camera is in control of the ND filter state. Just select one of the options from there: Off/In/Out Extra Photo Operations -> ND filter state With CHDK, you can keep the ND filter out, and just select a faster shutter speed to compensate. In CHDK, you can perform this operation by going to: With the ND filter in, the camera can select a slower shutter speed without over-exposing the entire scene. Also, with the ND filter swung in, the camera will capture an image with an aperture of f/8 - This is a fake aperture value caused by the ND filter swinging in. When your camera detects a really bright scene, it'll swing
